user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_connection_close_:
```c
void
MHD_connection_close_ (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                       enum MHD_RequestTerminationCode termination_code)
{
  struct MHD_Daemon *daemon = connection->daemon;
  struct MHD_Response *resp = connection->rp.response;

  mhd_assert (! connection->suspended);
#ifdef MHD_USE_THREADS
  mhd_assert ( (! MHD_D_IS_USING_THREADS_ (daemon)) || \
               MHD_thread_handle_ID_is_current_thread_ (connection->tid) );
#endif /* MHD_USE_THREADS */
  if ( (NULL != daemon->notify_completed) &&
       (connection->rq.client_aware) )
    daemon->notify_completed (daemon->notify_completed_cls,
                              connection,
                              &connection->rq.client_context,
                              termination_code);
  connection->rq.client_aware = false;
  if (NULL != resp)
  {
    connection->rp.response = NULL;
    MHD_destroy_response (resp);
  }
  if (NULL != connection->pool)
  {
    MHD_pool_destroy (connection->pool);
    connection->pool = NULL;
  }

  MHD_connection_mark_closed_ (connection);
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
daemon->notify_completed (daemon->notify_completed_cls,
                              connection,
                              &connection->rq.client_context,
                              termination_code);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Cannot be determined from the fragment alone. The call passes &connection->rq.client_context (a pointer to a non-const object) to daemon->notify_completed. This is not a MISRA 8.13 violation by itself. A violation would occur only if the function-pointer type daemon->notify_completed is declared to take a non-const pointer but the callback does not (and need not) modify the pointed-to data — in that case the parameter should be const-qualified. If notify_completed is declared to accept a const-qualified pointer (or if it legitimately modifies the client_context), there is no violation.
